dialogue_content.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: I'd love to hear about your apprenticeship in Paris.

dialogue_content.original_text: I was just a young lad, around 16 or 17.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: I remember the early mornings, the smell of fresh bread filling the streets.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: My mentor was a tough man, Monsieur Lefevre.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: It sounds like Monsieur Lefevre had a big impact on your life. What was it like working under him?

dialogue_content.original_text: He was a hard taskmaster, no doubt.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: That must have been hard, but it sounds like it shaped you into the baker you became. So when did things change?

dialogue_content.original_text: Things changed when I finished my apprenticeship and decided to try my luck in America.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: I was around 22, and I wanted to bring the taste of French pastries to New York.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: What was it like starting out in New York?

dialogue_content.original_text: Starting out in New York was a whirlwind.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: I didn't have much money, just a small space in the Lower East Side.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: That sounds like quite the challenge, Pierre. What were some of the biggest hurdles you faced during that time?

dialogue_content.original_text: The biggest hurdle was building a customer base.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: People in New York had different tastes, and convincing them to try my French pastries was tough.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: That must have been incredibly stressful, trying to make ends meet while staying true to your craft. Did you ever reach a point where things started to get easier?

dialogue_content.original_text: Word of mouth was powerful, and the locals began to appreciate the authenticity of my pastries.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: I remember the first time a customer came in and said my croissants reminded them of Paris; that was a turning point.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: That sounds like a significant turning point. What was it like realizing you were losing your sense of smell?

dialogue_content.original_text: At first, I thought it was just a temporary thing, maybe a cold or allergies.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: That must have been incredibly difficult, Pierre. How did you cope with that change in your life?

dialogue_content.original_text: I had to rely more on my other senses, like touch and sight, to know when the dough was ready or when something was perfectly baked.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: I found ways to adapt, and thankfully, I had a team I trusted to help me with things I could no longer do alone.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: It sounds like you've faced quite a few challenges throughout your life. How do you feel looking back on everything now?

dialogue_content.original_text: And even though I couldn't smell the bread, I could still see the joy in my customers' faces when they tasted it.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: Before we finish, Pierre, if you were to pass on one lesson you've learned from your journey to the next generation of bakers or anyone pursuing their passions, what would it be?

dialogue_content.original_text: Rely on others, build a team you trust.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
